descendants.content:
@Fury Even having the option to go remotely is awesome.
So then the main question is: why are you going to the conference?
a) To learn stuff? In which case, going remotely would be fine.
b) To make contacts? Unless there are things there like group discussions, the opportunities to make good contacts will be random, because during the actual sessions, people will be listening to the speaker, not talking to each other. The times for talking to each other will be when people are waiting in queues or eating, and that... is going to be completely up to serendipity.
c) To present papers? In which case, you'll need to be there.
d) Something else? I don't know.

account.note: Proudly leftist southpaw. Theist. Older than Star Trek, younger than Doctor Who. Artist. Artisan. Programmer. Occasional poet. Liable to spout random opinions and observations about Life, The Universe, and Everything.

descendants.content: @kerravonsen I will be presenting a paper. Which I can do remotely. The problem is, the little interactions cannot be replicated. Making contacts could be good for future job prospects.

descendants.content:
@Fury Making connections is helpful, but if it's a huge/costly effort to go in person I'd look for other ways to build those connections.

Some ideas:
* Emailing interesting presenters about their talks,
* Following interesting presenters on here or elsewhere,
* If you have a way of getting in touch with other remote presenters, I've really enjoyed doing an online watch party before. We watch a session live or recorded at the same time, and then do a video call or text chat afterwards/during to discuss it.

descendants.content:
@Fury I've also given up an travelling for conferences, in part because the climate impact didn't feel worth what I was getting from them.

Mind you, my research is not flying along right now!

From my own limited experience of academia (which may not be generally true) a lot depends on being flexible, curious, and lucky.

Doing 'everything right' (in terms of publishing, networking, etc) helps I'm sure, but I didn't and I've largely been happy with how things have gone.

I'm mostly teaching right now, but I have secure and flexible half-time work and I love teaching.

descendants.content:
@Fury I don't know how things are in your field so obviously take all this with a pinch of salt, but I think if you're prepared to do teaching as well as research, it helps.

And overall, I think finding your own path works a lot better than trying to tick all the boxes. You may not get the fanciest job (or you may??), but hopefully you'll be building a better version of academia and be more likely to find people and spaces that work for you <3

descendants.content:
@Fury Tricky. I personally feel -- and I could be wrong -- that it looks better if the speaker is actually there.
On the other hand, another thing to keep in mind is that as a #Diabetic, you'll be immunocompromised, and conferences are a hotbed of infection vectors, with so many people crowded together.

descendants.content: @Fury Do you really think you are going to get an academic career? I know it sounds brutal but honestly it is most likely that you will not. Your tiny chance of getting an academic job hinges on having to perpetuate the academic publishing crime ring that is destroying academia. Can you live with that?

account.note:
Virtually Real

"We each live in our own perceptual universe, no two sensoria are exactly alike, but, because we all live in the same physical universe, we imagine it is a shared whole, its entirety common to us all. But our perceptual worlds are as unique as we each are, each unique perceptual world adding to the creation of the whole of reality."

Theologian. Historian. Virtual World Developer. Polytheist Animist. Regenerative Farmer. Refugee From Academia. Open Data Advocate. Photographer.

descendants.content: @Fury If you are aiming for an academic career, physically going to the conference is a must. If you present remotely, especially if you are not well known in your field, no one will remember your presentation. It sucks, but networking is essential to advancing an academic career. I know this as someone who did a PHD in Australia, and had very limited networking opportunities until I moved to Europe.

descendants.content:
@Fury I know this is slightly off topic but conference organisers *really* need to get their act together. There is *so* much they can do to replicate the in-person experience virtually.

But this requires a leadership that fully grasp the crisis we are in and design everything they do accordingly. That of course is the greatest challenge of all - changing the minds of the old guard.

account.note:
𝗙𝗼𝘂𝗻𝗱𝗲𝗿: FutureWork IQ | I speak about mitigation and adaptation in the face of the climate crisis | b. 316 ppm | 🇿🇦

𝗠𝘆 𝗠𝗮𝘀𝘁𝗼𝗱𝗼𝗻 𝗣𝗼𝗹𝗶𝗰𝘆: Posts are set to auto delete after 60 days in an endeavour to assist with keeping server storage at a minimum. Important archives on listed blogs!

descendants.content:
@Fury Ugh, as someone who has just recently actively decided against an academic career, this is another reason I didn't even consider. Traveling! I do love me some traveling but not for work.

Also, I keep forgetting how fucking huge Australia is. If I see it correctly, going to Brisbane is not even half as far as you could travel without leaving the state.

account.note:
M. Sc. who has worked as developer, nurse & mechanic; is gamer, woodworker & cosplayer. Passionate about music, will occasionally post about Techno. Likes rhythm games and Final Fantasy.

You can hire me. I am great at solving problems with code. I've been coding for 15 years, with Unity for over 2 years now. I live in Germany but also work remotely. Check out my game jam projects on Itch. I am also dev & playtester for 9 Dystricts https://bikanel.de/9dy

descendants.content:
@Fury The main conference in my field (AIDS2024) has fully hybrid delivery, and its platform includes functions that let you find and chat and network with other attendees... and nobody uses them. I think the barriers are social rather than technical.

Earlier this year I co-authored a paper at an NZ confie with a friend and colleague. I Zoomed in to deliver my bit and take part in Q&A. I actually felt included and represented because of that collaboration. Could that be an option for you?

account.note: PhD researcher in regulation and governance, studying how communities mobilise to reconfigure the regulation of licit and illicit drugs. I'm queer and trans (nonbinary, they/them pronouns) and a person with disability.

descendants.content: @engagedpractx My main conference is face to face only. So I reckon I’m going to have to go to that one. I am going to complain about it. Especially since it’s supposed to be about sustainable architecture!!!! 😡😡😡 people wear climate blinders 🤷🏻‍♀️🤷🏻‍♀️

descendants.content:
@Fury
I think I agree with the other advice here. My experience over the last couple of years is also that hybrid mode is great if you want to learn, but the in-person delegates are doing the networking. It doesn't matter how good the hybrid system might be set up, the in person delegates are there to learn, socialise, etc. and don't interact with the online delegates.

Is there one conference that would select to be the best for you for the networking you need to do for your career?

And on COVID, I went to a in-person conference of about 100 people last month and around 10% got COVID. Conference dinners and socials still seem to be the spreader events.

account.note:
At work, a cave and groundwater scientist researching past climates, fires and groundwater recharge. Employed at UNSW Sydney, Australia, lives on unceded lands of the Kuring-gai and Darkinjung (the NSW Central Coast).

Also likely to post about wildlife, hiking, caving with the Kempsey Speleological Society, running, pets, books, and music.
